answer.response: Investing in startups is a risky proposition, but the low requirement for overhead capital combined with high upside potential makes it lucrative for investors to put their bets on startups. answer.response:
A DPIIT-recognized Startup is eligible to apply to the Inter-Ministerial Board for a full deduction on the profits and gains from business under Section 80-IAC of the Income Tax Act, provided that the following eligibility criteria are fulfilled:
a) The entity should be a Private Limited Company or a Limited Liability Partnership;
b) The entity should be incorporated on or after 1st April 2016 but before 1st April 2023;
c) The Startup’s products or services have the potential for commercialization and have significant incremental value for customers or workflow.
To apply for 80-IAC Exemption, clickhere.

answer.response:
Below are the tax benefits available under Startup India Initiative for DPIIT recognized startups:
1. Section 80-IAC of Income Tax Act: full deduction on the profits and gains from business provided eligibility criteria are fulfilled.
2. Section 56 (2)(vii-b): when a Startup receives any consideration for the issue of shares that exceeds the Fair Market Value of such shares.
3. A Startup fulfilling conditions mentioned in para 4 (i) and para 4 (ii) shall file a duly signed declaration in Form 2 to DIPP that it fulfills the conditions mentioned in para 4. On receipt of such declaration, the DPIIT shall forward the same to the CBDT
4. Section 54GB: Capital gain on transfer of residential property not to be charged if the amount is invested in subscription of the equity shares of the eligible Startup as defined in Section 80-IAC subject to certain conditions.
5. Section 79: Eligible Startup to carry forward their losses on satisfaction of any one of the two conditions: A. Continuity of 51% shareholding/voting power or B. Continuity of 100% of original shareholders carrying voting power
OR If all the shareholders with voting power on the last day of the year or years of loss, continue to hold those shares on the last day of such previous year and loss has been incurred during the period of seven years from company incorporation.
6. Sections 156, 191, and 192: Deferment of tax liability on ESOPs or sweat equity shares for employees of eligible Startup or TDS by the Startup employer.You can find more details about this in this notification.

A DPIIT recognized Startup is eligible to apply to the Inter-Ministerial Board for a full deduction on the profits and gains from business under Section 80-IAC of the Income Tax Act, provided that the following eligibility criteria are fulfilled:
a) The entity should be a Private Limited Company or a Limited Liability Partnership;
b) The entity should be incorporated on or after 1st April 2016, but before 1st April 2023;
c) The Startup’s products or services have potential for commercialization and have significant incremental value for customers or workflow.

answer.response:
An entity shall be considered as a startup if it fulfills the following eligibility criteria:
1) If it is incorporated as either a Private Limited Company or Registered Partnership Firm or Limited Liability Partnership. A sole proprietorship or a public limited company is not eligible as a Startup
2) If it is up to 10 years from the date of its incorporation
3) If its turnover for any of the financial years has not exceeded INR 100 crore
4) If it is working towards innovation, development or improvement of products or processes or services, or if it is a scalable business model with a high potential of employment generation or wealth creation.
The entity should not have been formed by splitting up or reconstructing a business already in existence.
To get your startup recognized, click on DPIIT Recognition for Startups in the Schemes and Policies menu.

answer.response:
The GeM Startup Runway is a unique concept initiated by Government eMarketplace in partnership with Startup India to promote entrepreneurship through innovation. This program is an opportunity for agile and lean startups to reach out to the universe of Government buyers by offering products and services that are unique in concept, design, process, and functionality. DPIIT recognized startups get the following benefits on GeM:
- Exemptions on Prior Experience, Prior Turnover, and Earnest Money Deposit requirements for startups.
-Feedback mechanism for the buyers to rate the startup products and help the startup finetune their innovations.
- Removal of category issues on GeM for startups, enabling innovative products and services to be published on a Government platform.
#Please follow the below steps to register on GeM:
1. Visit gem.gov.in/.
2. Signup as a Seller.

answer.response:
The definition of Startup means an entity recognised by Department for Promotion of Industry and Internal. Here, an entity shall be considered as a Startup:
i. Up to a period of 10 years from the date of incorporation/ registration, if it is incorporated as a private limited company (as defined Companies Act, 2013) or registered as a partnership firm (registered under section 59 of the Partnership Act, 1932) or a limited liability partnership (under the Limited Liability Partnership Act 2008) in India.
ii. Turnover of the entity for any of the financial years since incorporation/ registration has not exceeded INR 100 Crore.
iii. Entity is working towards innovation, development, or improvement of products or processes or services, or if it is a scalable business model with a high potential of employment generation or wealth creation.
Provided that an entity formed by splitting up or reconstruction of an existing business shall not be considered a Startup.
To read more on the definition kindly refer this Gazette Notification

answer.response:
The process of recognition as a Startup is through an online application made over the mobile app/portal at www.startupindia.gov.in. You will need to upload the following documents:
1) Incorporation/Registration Certificate and explain how your startup is working towards innovation, development, or improvement of products or processes or services, or its scalability in terms of employment generation or wealth creation.
2) Proof of concept (website link/video/pitch deck) showcasing the product or service is required for startups in the validation stage.
3) For the early traction and scaling stage, it is necessary to provide a video or pitch deck in addition to a company website.
4) Ideation stage startups are not mandated to submit a proof of concept.
To get your startup recognized, go to DPIIT recognition for Startups link of Schemes and Policy menu.

An entity which fulfils the eligibility conditions as notified in G.S.R. 127 (E), dated 19th February 2019 can apply for exemption under Section 56(2)(vii-b)

answer.response:
The process of recognition as a startup is through an online application made over the portal set up by the Department for Promotion of Industry and Internal Trade.
Please note that you will need to upload an Incorporation/Registration Certificate and explain how your startup is working towards innovation, development, or improvement of products or processes or services or its scalability in terms of employment generation or wealth creation.
A proof of concept (website link/video/pitch deck) showcasing the product or service is required for startups in the validation stage. For the early traction and scaling stage, it is necessary to provide a video or pitch deck in addition to a company website. Ideation stage startups are not mandated to submit a proof of concept.
An authorization letter will have to be attached in the format specified in the recognition form. Ensure that it’s on the company letterhead and signed and stamped by at least one director.
To get your startup recognized click on this link: here .

answer.response:
For Section 80-IAC - Post receiving the application, the IMB Secretariat verifies the documents within 7 working days. If the application is complete, the same is sent to the technical agency (NRDC) for further evaluation. If the application is incomplete, the comments are sent to the startup with an edit link. The technical agency evaluates the application as per certain criteria like legalities, innovativeness, and scalability. The applications recommended by the technical agency are presented in the upcoming Inter-Ministerial Board meeting, while the applications which are not found suitable are rejected or are kept on hold and sent comments to provide clarifications. The entire process can take any time, between 30-90 days.
For Section 56 - Upon receiving the application with the declaration form, the Startup India team forwards them to the Central Board of Direct Taxes (CBDT) within a period of 3-4 working days for processing.
  • The declaration forms submitted by startups which are found complete by CBDT are issued with an intimation mail regarding receipt of Declaration in Form
  • If the declaration form is found incomplete, CBDT intimates the same to Startup India. team.

Further, Startup India intimates the startup on the deficiency within 7 working days of receiving the comments and the startup is requested to resubmit the form with the changes through the dashboard.

answer.response:
A recognized startup, if changes its sector and/or industry AND has a change in its CIN/incorporation number, its existing certificate of recognition shall be cancelled. The Startup will need to apply for a fresh recognition application which will be reviewed independently. In this case, please submit a formal cancellation request on the company’s letterhead* along with the reason for cancellation and your new certificate of incorporation due to the change in CIN.
However, if a recognised startup only wants to update/change its sector and/or industry without changing its CIN/incorporation number, please submit a formal request to change/update the existing recognition certificate on the company’s letterhead* along with producing the relevant information like the entity’s name, incorporation/registration number, DPIIT number, Director Identification number/ Designated Partner’s Identification Number wherever applicable along with the reason for changing/updating the sector and/or industry.
*The letterhead will have to be stamped and signed by at least one of the directors of the company and sent from one of the email IDs mentioned in the recognition form (email address of any director/authorized representative)
Additionally, please submit a Proof of Concepts, such as a Pitch Deck which should cover the work of your company, details about the founding team, your USP, business model, and growth prospects. It should provide a holistic picture of the company.

answer.response:
An online application form along with documents and fees is to be submitted on the website to the Registrar of Firms of the State in which the firm is situated. The application must be signed by all partners or their agents.
Documents to be submitted to Registrar are:
  • Application for registration of partnership (Form 1)
  • Specimen of Affidavit
  • Certified original copy of Partnership Deed
  • Proof of principal place of business (ownership documents or rental/lease agreement)
  • Pan Card, Aadhar card, Driving License, passport, and voter Id Card of all Partners.

If the registrar is satisfied with the documents, he will register the firm in Register of Firms and issue Certificate of Registration.

A DPIIT-recognized Startup is eligible to apply to the Inter-Ministerial Board for a full deduction on the profits and gains from business (exemption under Section 80-IAC of the Income Tax Act) provided the following conditions are fulfilled. The entity should be:
  • A private limited company or a limited liability partnership,
  • Incorporated on or after 1st April 2016 but before 1st April 2022, and
  • Products or services or processes are undifferentiated, have potential for commercialization and have significant incremental value for customers or workflow

To avail the tax benefit, a Startup must get a Certificate of Eligibility from the Inter-Ministerial Board (IMB).

answer.response:
DPIIT-recognized Startups are exempt from tax under Section 56(2)(vii-b) of the Income Tax Act when such a Startup receives any consideration for issue of shares which exceeds the Fair Market Value of such shares. The startup has to file a duly signed declaration in Form 2 to DPIIT {as per notification G.S.R. 127 (E)} to claim the exemption from the provisions of Section 56(2) (vii-b) of the Income Tax Act.
A Startup shall be eligible for notification under clause (ii) of the proviso to clause (vii-b) of sub-section (2) of section 56 of the Act and consequent exemption from the provisions of that clause, if it fulfils the following conditions:
  1. It has been recognised by DPIIT under para 2(iii)(a) or as per any earlier notification on the subject
  2. Aggregate amount of paid-up share capital and share premium of the startup after issue or proposed issue of share, if any, does not exceed, twenty five crore rupees:

Refer to the attached notification for details: here
Post getting recognition a Startup may apply for exemption under Section 56 (2) (vii-b) of the Income Tax Act.
Link to apply is here .

answer.response:
The Startup which has raised money in the past or/and which has a proposed investment may apply for exemption provided the following conditions are fulfilled:
A Startup shall be eligible for notification under clause (ii) of the proviso to clause (viib) of sub-section (2) of section 56 of the Act and consequent exemption from the provisions of that clause, if it fulfils the following conditions:
(i) it has been recognised by DPIIT under para 2(iii)(a) or as per any earlier notification on the subject
(ii) aggregate amount of paid up share capital and share premium of the startup after issue or proposed issue of share, if any, does not exceed, twenty five crore rupees:
Provided that in computing the aggregate amount of paid up share capital, the amount of paid up share capital and share premium of twenty five crore rupees in respect of shares issued to any of the following persons shall not be included─
(a) a non-resident; or
(b) a venture capital company or a venture capital fund; Provided further that considerations received by such startup for shares issued or proposed to be issued to a specified company shall also be exempt and shall not be included in computing the aggregate amount of paid up share capital and share premium of twenty five crore rupees.
A startup fulfilling conditions mentioned in para 4 (i) and para 4 (ii) shall file a duly signed declaration in Form 2 to DIPP that it fulfils the conditions mentioned in para 4. On receipt of such declaration, the DPIIT shall forward the same to the CBDT.
You can find more details about this in this notification here .

Startup India Seed Fund Scheme (SISFS) shall provide financial assistance to startups for proof of concept, prototype development, product trials, market-entry, and commercialization. The Seed Fund will be disbursed to startups through selected incubators across India.
nAny Indian incubator operational for at least two years (Government-assisted incubators) or for three years (Incubators not assisted by the Government so far) on the date of application can apply.
Further, the incubator must be a legal entity:
  • A society registered under the Societies Registration Act 1860, or
  • A Trust registered under the Indian Trusts Act 1882, or
  • A Private Limited company registered under the Companies Act 1956 or the Companies Act 2013, or
  • · A statutory body created through an Act of the legislature.

answer.response:
Below are the tax benefits available under Startup India Initiative for DPIIT recognized startups:
1. Section 80-IAC of Income Tax Act: full deduction on the profits and gains from business provided eligibility criteria are fulfilled.
2. Section 56 (2)(vii-b): when a Startup receives any consideration for the issue of shares that exceeds the Fair Market Value of such shares.
3. A Startup fulfilling conditions mentioned in para 4 (i) and para 4 (ii) shall file a duly signed declaration in Form 2 to DIPP that it fulfills the conditions mentioned in para 4. On receipt of such declaration, the DPIIT shall forward the same to the CBDT
4. Section 54GB: Capital gain on transfer of residential property not to be charged if the amount is invested in subscription of the equity shares of the eligible Startup as defined in Section 80-IAC subject to certain conditions.
5. Section 79: Eligible Startup to carry forward their losses on satisfaction of any one of the two conditions: A. Continuity of 51% shareholding/voting power or B. Continuity of 100% of original shareholders carrying voting power
OR If all the shareholders with voting power on the last day of the year or years of loss, continue to hold those shares on the last day of such previous year and loss has been incurred during the period of seven years from company incorporation.
6. Sections 156, 191, and 192: Deferment of tax liability on ESOPs or sweat equity shares for employees of eligible Startup or TDS by the Startup employer.You can find more details about this in this notification.
